laws.summary: North Carolina traditionally enforces reasonable non-compete agreements. However, House Bill 269 (Workforce Freedom and Protection Act) proposed in 2025 would ban non-competes for employees earning less than $75,000/year. As of January 2026, this bill is PROPOSED but NOT YET LAW. Current law allows reasonable non-competes if supported by consideration and protecting legitimate business interests.
laws.statute_citation: Common law; Proposed H.B. 269 (not yet enacted as of Jan 2026)
requirements: CURRENT LAW: Non-competes enforceable if reasonable in scope, duration, and geography
CURRENT LAW: Must be in writing and part of employment contract
CURRENT LAW: Must be supported by valuable consideration (employment, continued employment, promotion, training, confidential information access)
CURRENT LAW: Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, specialized training)
CURRENT LAW: Courts will not rewrite overly broad agreements (all-or-nothing approach)
CURRENT LAW: Typical duration: 1-2 years
CURRENT LAW: Geographic scope must be reasonable for employer's business operations
PROPOSED H.B. 269: Would prohibit non-competes for employees earning less than $75,000/year
PROPOSED H.B. 269: Would not apply to agreements entered before effective date
PROPOSED H.B. 269: Would still allow non-competes for higher earners ($75k+)
PROPOSED H.B. 269: Would also restrict franchise non-poaching agreements
Status: Bill introduced March 2025, not yet passed as of Jan 2026
laws.effective_date: Current law ongoing; H.B. 269 proposed but not enacted
laws.notes: North Carolina may significantly change non-compete landscape if H.B. 269 passes. Currently, NC is employer-friendly on non-competes but uses strict 'all-or-nothing' approach (won't modify agreements).

laws.summary: North Carolina has NO statewide salary history ban. Employers may ask about and consider applicant salary history when setting compensation. Some local jurisdictions may have restrictions, but no state-level prohibition exists.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No restriction on asking about salary history
STATEWIDE: Employers may ask applicants about prior compensation
STATEWIDE: Employers may use salary history in setting compensation
STATEWIDE: No penalties for inquiring about salary history
Equal pay laws still apply (federal EPA and Title VII)
Employers increasingly adopt voluntary salary history bans for equity
laws.notes: North Carolina has not enacted salary history ban legislation. Employers have broad discretion.

laws.summary: North Carolina has NO statewide pay transparency law requiring salary ranges in job postings. No requirement to disclose compensation ranges to applicants or employees. No pay data reporting mandates.
requirements: STATEWIDE: No requirement to include salary ranges in job postings
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to applicants
STATEWIDE: No requirement to disclose pay ranges to current employees
STATEWIDE: No pay data reporting requirements
Federal equal pay laws still apply (Equal Pay Act, Title VII)
Employers may voluntarily disclose pay ranges
laws.notes: North Carolina has not enacted pay transparency legislation. Employers not required to post salary ranges.

laws.summary: North Carolina has limited background check restrictions. No statewide ban-the-box law for private employers. Employers may ask about criminal history on applications. Must comply with federal FCRA requirements. Seven-year lookback limit on most criminal records under FCRA.
laws.statute_citation: Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681); N.C. Gen. Stat. § 126-7.1 (state employees only)
requirements: PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: Can ask about criminal history on applications
PRIVATE EMPLOYERS: No ban-the-box restrictions
STATE AGENCIES: Limited criminal history inquiry restrictions
FCRA: Must get written consent before background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action notice with copy of report
FCRA: Must provide final adverse action notice with dispute rights
FCRA: Seven-year lookback for: civil suits/judgments, arrests without conviction, paid tax liens, collection accounts
FCRA: Ten-year lookback for bankruptcies
FCRA: No time limit on convictions
FCRA: $75,000+ salary positions exempt from lookback limits
Cannot discriminate based solely on arrest without conviction
Must consider: nature of crime, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
laws.notes: North Carolina is employer-friendly with minimal state restrictions. Federal FCRA is primary regulation.

laws.summary: North Carolina has NO statewide paid sick leave or paid leave mandate for private employers. No state law requires employers to provide paid or unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA. Employers may voluntarily offer paid leave benefits.
laws.statute_citation: No North Carolina statute; Federal FMLA (29 U.S.C. § 2601)
requirements: STATEWIDE: No requirement for paid sick leave
STATEWIDE: No requirement for unpaid sick leave beyond federal FMLA
Private employers not required to provide sick leave benefits
Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees: up to 12 weeks unpaid leave
FMLA requirements: employee worked 1,250 hours in past 12 months, employed 12+ months, employer has 50+ employees within 75 miles
Employers may establish own sick leave policies
No state penalties for lack of paid leave
laws.notes: North Carolina has no paid leave mandates. Employer-friendly state on leave policies.

laws.summary: North Carolina generally enforces arbitration agreements in employment contracts under federal law and common law. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Agreements must be clear, mutual, and not unconscionable. State courts favor arbitration.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); North Carolina common law
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and signed by both parties
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable or one-sided
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Adequate consideration required
North Carolina courts favor arbitration
Class action waivers generally enforceable
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable
Can be challenged on contract formation grounds (fraud, duress, unconscionability)
Federal policy favoring arbitration applies
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: North Carolina is arbitration-friendly. Courts rarely invalidate valid agreements.

laws.summary: North Carolina follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate employment at any time for any legal reason or no reason. Exceptions exist for discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and breach of contract.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; N.C. Gen. Stat. § 143-422.2 (anti-discrimination)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid by next regular payday
EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age 40+, disability, genetic information discrimination
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (workers' comp claim, jury duty, whistleblowing, military service)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy (refusing illegal acts, reporting violations)
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract (written or implied)
Employment handbooks may create implied contracts if not properly disclaimed
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
North Carolina courts narrowly construe at-will exceptions
laws.notes: North Carolina is at-will employment state with typical exceptions. Handbook disclaimers recommended.

laws.summary: North Carolina has NO state statute restricting private employer drug testing. Employers may conduct pre-employment, random, reasonable suspicion, and post-accident testing. Recommended to have written policy. Workers' compensation benefits may be affected by positive drug tests.
laws.statute_citation: N.C. Gen. Stat. § 95-230 et seq. (workers' comp drug testing provisions); No general restriction statute
requirements: STATEWIDE: No restriction on private employer drug testing
Pre-employment testing: Permitted
Random testing: Permitted
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted
Post-accident testing: Permitted
Workers' comp: Positive drug test may reduce or eliminate benefits if intoxication contributed to injury
Workers' comp: Must conduct test within 24 hours of accident
Workers' comp: Must use approved testing methods
Recommended: Written drug testing policy
Recommended: Apply policy consistently
Federal DOT requirements apply to transportation/safety-sensitive positions
No state protections for medical or recreational marijuana users
laws.notes: North Carolina is employer-friendly on drug testing with no state restrictions. Drug testing can affect workers' comp claims.
